BIOS323
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module aims to develop understanding of methods and organisations involved in the control of animal diseases in populations.

It builds on numeracy and statistics introduced earlier in the programme, as well as drawing from modules in infection, although it will not be restricted to covering infectious diseases.
Students will hear from academics and leaders in a range of organisations actively involved in the research and control of animal diseases both working within and outside the University of Liverpool, both within the UK and overseas.

The module will be delivered through a series of lectures (two per week), mostly face-to-face, apart from those delivered by overseas researchers. These will be complemented by small group tutorials, each group working collaboratively, but independent of the other groups, on their own individual disease, how it is diagnosed and controlled. Importantly, they will analyse a related dataset to carry out real–world data cleaning, and epidemiological analyses – the results of this will be presented through a mini conference to the rest of their peers. The tutorials will take place once per week, with half supervised by a tutor, and half being self-directed.

In completing this module, students will develop the academic and transferable skills needed to work in, or study further, in the dynamic world of population disease control. For those going into veterinary training, this module will give an unparalleled insight into population health, opening up new career pathways for their veterinary degree.

The module is designed with research and future employer-connected teaching as students will interact with research staff and future potential employees through specific disease exemplars. Students will engage in active learning as they collaborate and reflect during tutorials and will complete authentic assessments to include a mini conference, a data analyses task and a leaflet design.
Educational Aims

- Enable students to apply epidemiological and public health concepts to animal diseases to understand how they contribute to global and One Health challenges
- Develop in students the ability to valuate key drivers of animal health surveillance, and gaps in coverage, as well as new ways to try and fill these gaps.
- Provide opportunities for students to develop foundational epidemiological skills necessary to investigate patterns, causes and effects of animal diseases in populations
Marketing Module Synopsis
Recognising the interconnection of animal and human health, the module will adopt a One Health approach throughout. Learners will study the legal and organisational processes in place in the UK and more widely to monitor, survey and control a range of diseases in animal populations. Learners will also examine how epidemiology is used to identify abnormal patterns of disease in such populations.

The module will be delivered by staff with active research in relevant areas. Its assessment will include data analayis, writing for key stakeholders, as well as a group oral presentation. Together these assessments will help develop vital skills for future employability, wherever your degree takes you.

At the end of this module learners will be able to take the holistic, end to end approach necessary to understand diseases in a wide range of species and to discuss these diseases with a diversity of stakeholders from policy makers to animal keepers and their veterinarians, from researchers to commercial companies, from those interested in human health to NGOs. The module aims to develop skills that are vital for future employability in these wide-ranging sectors.
Outline Syllabus
Theme 1: Introduction to epidemiology

How Epidemiology impacts clinical veterinary medicine, animal health and public health.
How to use exemplar epidemiological methods to investigate the causes of disease and the effectiveness of treatments, and how to assess the importance of possible risk factors.
Arrangement and manipulation of data for statistical analysis.
How to use more advanced statistical techniques, such as logistic regression and other methods that are particularly relevant to research into disease and health.
Understanding disease transmission, R0 and outbreak investigation.
How common diagnostic tests work, and their usefulness for clinical diagnosis and for the control of diseases within populations.
An introduction to using mathematical models for infectious disease.
How to design relevant studies including clinical trials, randomisation and looking for causality.
How evidence informs the development of veterinary medicine.
How to critically review published and other literature.

Theme 2: Disease surveillance

Ways to classify disease in animals.
Ways to quantify disease impact.
Knowing the main national and international organisations that impact disease surveillance and related legislation in the UK.
How animal disease surveillance is carried out to include methods, drivers and legislation for farm animals, horses and small companion animals.
A gap analysis to identify what is missing.

Theme 3: Veterinary and human public health-related issues

Through case studies such animal and human food poisoning (such as feeding pets raw food), dog bites, occupational zoonoses, emerging infectious diseases, antimicrobial resistance, to understand the impact of animals on human health.
Teaching and Learning Methods
1. Teaching method: Lecture (20 hours)

Description: Face-to-face session
Students will have bi-weekly lectures to discuss content. As some of the types of assessment in this module may be new to some students, these lectures will also cover the format of these and allow for questions.

2. Teaching method: Seminars (5 hours)

Description: Government or charitable organisation or research institute (external to UoL)
Professionals covering a wide range of areas, such as policy making, specific animal industry sector issues, animal charity, international agencies will deliver seminars for students to attend. During these sessions’ students will learn about key animal health and disease areas from a business, animal welfare, One Health and governance perspective which will widen their knowledge of possible career opportunities. Students will have the opportunity to ask/submit questions online during these sessions.

3. Teaching method: Tutorials (15 hours)

Description: Small group work focussing on a particular animal disease area and associated dataset of interest
These will be fortnightly tutorial sessions which research staff will attend in the role of tutor to help students develop their ideas. The students will attend small group sessions every week (so 10 in total with research staff at 5 sessions to help guide). Working in small groups in the tutorial is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality among the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The culmination of these tutorials and small group working will be the mini conference presentation that they give as a group at the end of the module.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments for this module consist of three parts:
1) Design of an individual disease information leaflet,
2) A group mini-conference presentation and
3) An individual epidemiological (numeracy) test.

1) The ‘government- information-style' or industry sector leaflet on an animal disease/condition aimed either at the public or particular animal industry sector is an authentic assessment and will help develop written communication and digital fluency skills. This is also an example of an inclusive assessment as students can pick a topic based on their area of interest.

2) During the weekly series of small group tutorial sessions, the groups would work on a disease and data set of their choice which would culminate in a presentation at a mini conference. Assessment will be based on the groups presentation, with each individual student's marks moderated based on tutor and peer evaluation of their contributions to the tutorials. This is a second example of authentic assessment that covers both understnading of the topic as well as desirable skills like team working and communication.

3) The numeracy test will include computer-based analyses of a real data set to include data cleaning and analysis, preceded by a short-guided essay covering critical aspects of animal population health surveillance. The exam will take place under exam conditions in a campus computer suite.

Reassessment will use the same format for the 1 and 3 (disease information leaflet and the epidemiological test) but the topic or data will differ. For the mini conference, where it will not be possible to recreate the group process, reassessment will be offered as a structured essay. Marks will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically appraise the importance of epidemiology and statistics in animal/veterinary diseases and to appreciate its key role in One Health challenges.
 LO2 Apply and interpret epidemiological and statistical methods appropriately.
 LO3 Appraise the key stakeholders both within and outside of government in animal population health at international, national and regional levels, and how these work in the UK, with exemplars of differences in other national settings.
 LO4 Describe and analyse systems for classifying disease importance in populations, both infectious and non-infectious, including the importance of economics.
 LO5 Evaluate the range of diagnostic tests used in animal populations, and how to assess their accuracy and impact.
 LO6 Analyse, through examples, how a veterinary pathogens biology impacts on the disease it causes, and how this can be applied to aid its control.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Work as a team to investigate datasets and present effectively.
 S2 Enhance communication and group work skills.
 S3 Digital skills especially around presentations in written and oral formats.
 S4 Data science skills including data leaning and more advanced manipulation in Excel.

This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically appraise the importance of epidemiology and statistics in animal/veterinary diseases and to appreciate its key role in One Health challenges.
 LO2 Apply and interpret epidemiological and statistical methods appropriately.
 LO3 Appraise the key stakeholders both within and outside of government in animal population health at international, national and regional levels, and how these work in the UK, with exemplars of differences in other national settings.
 LO4 Describe and analyse systems for classifying disease importance in populations, both infectious and non-infectious, including the importance of economics.
 LO5 Evaluate the range of diagnostic tests used in animal populations, and how to assess their accuracy and impact.
 LO6 Analyse, through examples, how a veterinary pathogens biology impacts on the disease it causes, and how this can be applied to aid its control.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Work as a team to investigate datasets and present effectively.
 S2 Enhance communication and group work skills.
 S3 Digital skills especially around presentations in written and oral formats.
 S4 Data science skills including data leaning and more advanced manipulation in Excel.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module aims to develop understanding of methods and organisations involved in the control of animal diseases in populations.

It builds on numeracy and statistics introduced earlier in the programme, as well as drawing from modules in infection, although it will not be restricted to covering infectious diseases.
Students will hear from academics and leaders in a range of organisations actively involved in the research and control of animal diseases both working within and outside the University of Liverpool, both within the UK and overseas.

The module will be delivered through a series of lectures (two per week), mostly face-to-face, apart from those delivered by overseas researchers. These will be complemented by small group tutorials, each group working collaboratively, but independent of the other groups, on their own individual disease, how it is diagnosed and controlled. Importantly, they will analyse a related dataset to carry out real–world data cleaning, and epidemiological analyses – the results of this will be presented through a mini conference to the rest of their peers. The tutorials will take place once per week, with half supervised by a tutor, and half being self-directed.

In completing this module, students will develop the academic and transferable skills needed to work in, or study further, in the dynamic world of population disease control. For those going into veterinary training, this module will give an unparalleled insight into population health, opening up new career pathways for their veterinary degree.

The module is designed with research and future employer-connected teaching as students will interact with research staff and future potential employees through specific disease exemplars. Students will engage in active learning as they collaborate and reflect during tutorials and will complete authentic assessments to include a mini conference, a data analyses task and a leaflet design.
Educational Aims

- Enable students to apply epidemiological and public health concepts to animal diseases to understand how they contribute to global and One Health challenges
- Develop in students the ability to valuate key drivers of animal health surveillance, and gaps in coverage, as well as new ways to try and fill these gaps.
- Provide opportunities for students to develop foundational epidemiological skills necessary to investigate patterns, causes and effects of animal diseases in populations
Marketing Module Synopsis
Recognising the interconnection of animal and human health, the module will adopt a One Health approach throughout. Learners will study the legal and organisational processes in place in the UK and more widely to monitor, survey and control a range of diseases in animal populations. Learners will also examine how epidemiology is used to identify abnormal patterns of disease in such populations.

The module will be delivered by staff with active research in relevant areas. Its assessment will include data analayis, writing for key stakeholders, as well as a group oral presentation. Together these assessments will help develop vital skills for future employability, wherever your degree takes you.

At the end of this module learners will be able to take the holistic, end to end approach necessary to understand diseases in a wide range of species and to discuss these diseases with a diversity of stakeholders from policy makers to animal keepers and their veterinarians, from researchers to commercial companies, from those interested in human health to NGOs. The module aims to develop skills that are vital for future employability in these wide-ranging sectors.
Outline Syllabus
Theme 1: Introduction to epidemiology

How Epidemiology impacts clinical veterinary medicine, animal health and public health.
How to use exemplar epidemiological methods to investigate the causes of disease and the effectiveness of treatments, and how to assess the importance of possible risk factors.
Arrangement and manipulation of data for statistical analysis.
How to use more advanced statistical techniques, such as logistic regression and other methods that are particularly relevant to research into disease and health.
Understanding disease transmission, R0 and outbreak investigation.
How common diagnostic tests work, and their usefulness for clinical diagnosis and for the control of diseases within populations.
An introduction to using mathematical models for infectious disease.
How to design relevant studies including clinical trials, randomisation and looking for causality.
How evidence informs the development of veterinary medicine.
How to critically review published and other literature.

Theme 2: Disease surveillance

Ways to classify disease in animals.
Ways to quantify disease impact.
Knowing the main national and international organisations that impact disease surveillance and related legislation in the UK.
How animal disease surveillance is carried out to include methods, drivers and legislation for farm animals, horses and small companion animals.
A gap analysis to identify what is missing.

Theme 3: Veterinary and human public health-related issues

Through case studies such animal and human food poisoning (such as feeding pets raw food), dog bites, occupational zoonoses, emerging infectious diseases, antimicrobial resistance, to understand the impact of animals on human health.
Teaching and Learning Methods
1. Teaching method: Lecture (20 hours)

Description: Face-to-face session
Students will have bi-weekly lectures to discuss content. As some of the types of assessment in this module may be new to some students, these lectures will also cover the format of these and allow for questions.

2. Teaching method: Seminars (5 hours)

Description: Government or charitable organisation or research institute (external to UoL)
Professionals covering a wide range of areas, such as policy making, specific animal industry sector issues, animal charity, international agencies will deliver seminars for students to attend. During these sessions’ students will learn about key animal health and disease areas from a business, animal welfare, One Health and governance perspective which will widen their knowledge of possible career opportunities. Students will have the opportunity to ask/submit questions online during these sessions.

3. Teaching method: Tutorials (15 hours)

Description: Small group work focussing on a particular animal disease area and associated dataset of interest
These will be fortnightly tutorial sessions which research staff will attend in the role of tutor to help students develop their ideas. The students will attend small group sessions every week (so 10 in total with research staff at 5 sessions to help guide). Working in small groups in the tutorial is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality among the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The culmination of these tutorials and small group working will be the mini conference presentation that they give as a group at the end of the module.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments for this module consist of three parts:
1) Design of an individual disease information leaflet,
2) A group mini-conference presentation and
3) An individual epidemiological (numeracy) test.

1) The ‘government- information-style' or industry sector leaflet on an animal disease/condition aimed either at the public or particular animal industry sector is an authentic assessment and will help develop written communication and digital fluency skills. This is also an example of an inclusive assessment as students can pick a topic based on their area of interest.

2) During the weekly series of small group tutorial sessions, the groups would work on a disease and data set of their choice which would culminate in a presentation at a mini conference. Assessment will be based on the groups presentation, with each individual student's marks moderated based on tutor and peer evaluation of their contributions to the tutorials. This is a second example of authentic assessment that covers both understnading of the topic as well as desirable skills like team working and communication.

3) The numeracy test will include computer-based analyses of a real data set to include data cleaning and analysis, preceded by a short-guided essay covering critical aspects of animal population health surveillance. The exam will take place under exam conditions in a campus computer suite.

Reassessment will use the same format for the 1 and 3 (disease information leaflet and the epidemiological test) but the topic or data will differ. For the mini conference, where it will not be possible to recreate the group process, reassessment will be offered as a structured essay. Marks will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module aims to develop understanding of methods and organisations involved in the control of animal diseases in populations.

It builds on numeracy and statistics introduced earlier in the programme, as well as drawing from modules in infection, although it will not be restricted to covering infectious diseases.
Students will hear from academics and leaders in a range of organisations actively involved in the research and control of animal diseases both working within and outside the University of Liverpool, both within the UK and overseas.

The module will be delivered through a series of lectures (two per week), mostly face-to-face, apart from those delivered by overseas researchers. These will be complemented by small group tutorials, each group working collaboratively, but independent of the other groups, on their own individual disease, how it is diagnosed and controlled. Importantly, they will analyse a related dataset to carry out real–world data cleaning, and epidemiological analyses – the results of this will be presented through a mini conference to the rest of their peers. The tutorials will take place once per week, with half supervised by a tutor, and half being self-directed.

In completing this module, students will develop the academic and transferable skills needed to work in, or study further, in the dynamic world of population disease control. For those going into veterinary training, this module will give an unparalleled insight into population health, opening up new career pathways for their veterinary degree.

The module is designed with research and future employer-connected teaching as students will interact with research staff and future potential employees through specific disease exemplars. Students will engage in active learning as they collaborate and reflect during tutorials and will complete authentic assessments to include a mini conference, a data analyses task and a leaflet design.
Educational Aims

- Enable students to apply epidemiological and public health concepts to animal diseases to understand how they contribute to global and One Health challenges
- Develop in students the ability to valuate key drivers of animal health surveillance, and gaps in coverage, as well as new ways to try and fill these gaps.
- Provide opportunities for students to develop foundational epidemiological skills necessary to investigate patterns, causes and effects of animal diseases in populations
Marketing Module Synopsis
Recognising the interconnection of animal and human health, the module will adopt a One Health approach throughout. Learners will study the legal and organisational processes in place in the UK and more widely to monitor, survey and control a range of diseases in animal populations. Learners will also examine how epidemiology is used to identify abnormal patterns of disease in such populations.

The module will be delivered by staff with active research in relevant areas. Its assessment will include data analayis, writing for key stakeholders, as well as a group oral presentation. Together these assessments will help develop vital skills for future employability, wherever your degree takes you.

At the end of this module learners will be able to take the holistic, end to end approach necessary to understand diseases in a wide range of species and to discuss these diseases with a diversity of stakeholders from policy makers to animal keepers and their veterinarians, from researchers to commercial companies, from those interested in human health to NGOs. The module aims to develop skills that are vital for future employability in these wide-ranging sectors.
Outline Syllabus
Theme 1: Introduction to epidemiology

How Epidemiology impacts clinical veterinary medicine, animal health and public health.
How to use exemplar epidemiological methods to investigate the causes of disease and the effectiveness of treatments, and how to assess the importance of possible risk factors.
Arrangement and manipulation of data for statistical analysis.
How to use more advanced statistical techniques, such as logistic regression and other methods that are particularly relevant to research into disease and health.
Understanding disease transmission, R0 and outbreak investigation.
How common diagnostic tests work, and their usefulness for clinical diagnosis and for the control of diseases within populations.
An introduction to using mathematical models for infectious disease.
How to design relevant studies including clinical trials, randomisation and looking for causality.
How evidence informs the development of veterinary medicine.
How to critically review published and other literature.

Theme 2: Disease surveillance

Ways to classify disease in animals.
Ways to quantify disease impact.
Knowing the main national and international organisations that impact disease surveillance and related legislation in the UK.
How animal disease surveillance is carried out to include methods, drivers and legislation for farm animals, horses and small companion animals.
A gap analysis to identify what is missing.

Theme 3: Veterinary and human public health-related issues

Through case studies such animal and human food poisoning (such as feeding pets raw food), dog bites, occupational zoonoses, emerging infectious diseases, antimicrobial resistance, to understand the impact of animals on human health.
Teaching and Learning Methods
1. Teaching method: Lecture (20 hours)

Description: Face-to-face session
Students will have bi-weekly lectures to discuss content. As some of the types of assessment in this module may be new to some students, these lectures will also cover the format of these and allow for questions.

2. Teaching method: Seminars (5 hours)

Description: Government or charitable organisation or research institute (external to UoL)
Professionals covering a wide range of areas, such as policy making, specific animal industry sector issues, animal charity, international agencies will deliver seminars for students to attend. During these sessions’ students will learn about key animal health and disease areas from a business, animal welfare, One Health and governance perspective which will widen their knowledge of possible career opportunities. Students will have the opportunity to ask/submit questions online during these sessions.

3. Teaching method: Tutorials (15 hours)

Description: Small group work focussing on a particular animal disease area and associated dataset of interest
These will be fortnightly tutorial sessions which research staff will attend in the role of tutor to help students develop their ideas. The students will attend small group sessions every week (so 10 in total with research staff at 5 sessions to help guide). Working in small groups in the tutorial is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality among the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The culmination of these tutorials and small group working will be the mini conference presentation that they give as a group at the end of the module.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments for this module consist of three parts:
1) Design of an individual disease information leaflet,
2) A group mini-conference presentation and
3) An individual epidemiological (numeracy) test.

1) The ‘government- information-style' or industry sector leaflet on an animal disease/condition aimed either at the public or particular animal industry sector is an authentic assessment and will help develop written communication and digital fluency skills. This is also an example of an inclusive assessment as students can pick a topic based on their area of interest.

2) During the weekly series of small group tutorial sessions, the groups would work on a disease and data set of their choice which would culminate in a presentation at a mini conference. Assessment will be based on the groups presentation, with each individual student's marks moderated based on tutor and peer evaluation of their contributions to the tutorials. This is a second example of authentic assessment that covers both understnading of the topic as well as desirable skills like team working and communication.

3) The numeracy test will include computer-based analyses of a real data set to include data cleaning and analysis, preceded by a short-guided essay covering critical aspects of animal population health surveillance. The exam will take place under exam conditions in a campus computer suite.

Reassessment will use the same format for the 1 and 3 (disease information leaflet and the epidemiological test) but the topic or data will differ. For the mini conference, where it will not be possible to recreate the group process, reassessment will be offered as a structured essay. Marks will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Deliveries

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically appraise the importance of epidemiology and statistics in animal/veterinary diseases and to appreciate its key role in One Health challenges.
 LO2 Apply and interpret epidemiological and statistical methods appropriately.
 LO3 Appraise the key stakeholders both within and outside of government in animal population health at international, national and regional levels, and how these work in the UK, with exemplars of differences in other national settings.
 LO4 Describe and analyse systems for classifying disease importance in populations, both infectious and non-infectious, including the importance of economics.
 LO5 Evaluate the range of diagnostic tests used in animal populations, and how to assess their accuracy and impact.
 LO6 Analyse, through examples, how a veterinary pathogens biology impacts on the disease it causes, and how this can be applied to aid its control.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Work as a team to investigate datasets and present effectively.
 S2 Enhance communication and group work skills.
 S3 Digital skills especially around presentations in written and oral formats.
 S4 Data science skills including data leaning and more advanced manipulation in Excel.

These will be fortnightly tutorial sessions which research staff will attend in the role of tutor to help students develop their ideas. The students will attend small group sessions every week (so 10 in total with research staff at 5 sessions to help guide). Working in small groups in the tutorial is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality among the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The culmination of these tutorials and small group working will be the mini conference presentation that they give as a group at the end of the module.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments for this module consist of three parts:
1) Design of an individual disease information leaflet,
2) A group mini-conference presentation and
3) An individual epidemiological (numeracy) test.

1) The ‘government- information-style' or industry sector leaflet on an animal disease/condition aimed either at the public or particular animal industry sector is an authentic assessment and will help develop written communication and digital fluency skills. This is also an example of an inclusive assessment as students can pick a topic based on their area of interest.

2) During the weekly series of small group tutorial sessions, the groups would work on a disease and data set of their choice which would culminate in a presentation at a mini conference. Assessment will be based on the groups presentation, with each individual student's marks moderated based on tutor and peer evaluation of their contributions to the tutorials. This is a second example of authentic assessment that covers both understnading of the topic as well as desirable skills like team working and communication.

3) The numeracy test will include computer-based analyses of a real data set to include data cleaning and analysis, preceded by a short-guided essay covering critical aspects of animal population health surveillance. The exam will take place under exam conditions in a campus computer suite.

Reassessment will use the same format for the 1 and 3 (disease information leaflet and the epidemiological test) but the topic or data will differ. For the mini conference, where it will not be possible to recreate the group process, reassessment will be offered as a structured essay. Marks will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically appraise the importance of epidemiology and statistics in animal/veterinary diseases and to appreciate its key role in One Health challenges.
 LO2 Apply and interpret epidemiological and statistical methods appropriately.
 LO3 Appraise the key stakeholders both within and outside of government in animal population health at international, national and regional levels, and how these work in the UK, with exemplars of differences in other national settings.
 LO4 Describe and analyse systems for classifying disease importance in populations, both infectious and non-infectious, including the importance of economics.
 LO5 Evaluate the range of diagnostic tests used in animal populations, and how to assess their accuracy and impact.
 LO6 Analyse, through examples, how a veterinary pathogens biology impacts on the disease it causes, and how this can be applied to aid its control.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Work as a team to investigate datasets and present effectively.
 S2 Enhance communication and group work skills.
 S3 Digital skills especially around presentations in written and oral formats.
 S4 Data science skills including data leaning and more advanced manipulation in Excel.

The aims box is still not quite right. This should be a bulleted list of 2-3 aims … indicating what the teacher is aiming to achieve. For example:
- Enable students to apply epidemiological and public health concepts to animal diseases to understand how they contribute to global and One Health challenges
